(re: the UN) It means look around. Why do you think I’m sitting here? Somewhere there’s a war. In a place you can’t pronounce. For reasons you can’t understand. Our job is to stop it. It’s hard work. Tobin steps down the hallway, slowly, carefully. The door is only ten feet away.

TWO AFRICAN MEN breathe heavily, frozen on the stairs in flight. We recognize one of them as the Janitor. The seco man is painfully thin, terrified. Their faces are illumin from below. Nils Lud stands just inside the street door, holding a la gun pointed at the ground (he’s just entered as the men w about to exit). He looks at them with absolute neutrality Suddenly, footsteps can be heard running down the third f stairs. Lud holds up a wait finger to the Africans and po back up the stairs. He knows them. The footsteps run onto second-floor landing. The Africans exchange a look. Reluctantly, the Janitor takes a handgun out of his belt turns around. The Skinny African starts to protest but he Lud’s weapon click and turns to see it pointed at him. He draws a small handgun and assumes a position a few ste down. The agents footsteps now run the second-floor stair The attackers wait. As they footsteps hit the landing overhead, Lud aims at t back of the Janitor’s skull and fires.
Tobin, Dot, Doug and the FBI Agents fall back against the wall as two more rounds blast right beneath them. Dead silence.
Agent Keller?
Lud?!
Lud has shot both Africans: the Janitor in the back of th head; the skinny man, in the chest, then forehead.

I believe we are secure.  61. INT. TOBIN’S SPARE BEDROOM The door creaks. Tobin turns on the light. The room is carpeted and newly painted and completely emp except for a neat pile of packing boxes in the very cente Each box is labelled with black marker: JENN. Tobin runs his hand over the boxes, lost in thought.
INT. SILVIA’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Silvia bends by the kitchen counter and checks herself in reflection of a toaster. The doorbell rings. She opens the door wide for Tobin.
I bet you don’t recycle, either.
Hey.
Apology accepted.
You heard?
It was on the news. A awkward beat. She’s thrown by his reticence.
Congratulations. She hugs him. It’s uncomfortable. The sort of hug of two people who have imagined touching. A beat. He can’t start.
I was married. For six years. My wife died eighteen months ago. Of cancer.
I’m sorry. His subject choice tells her something’s wrong.  62.
What is it?
Edgar.
What? Has something happened? What about him? His silence is telling, damning. He finally opens his mou but she quickly puts her fingers on his lips.
Wait. After a moment, she jerks back her hand and holds it, fro a terrible fear. is finally being realized.
A month is a long time.
Don’t. Whatever you think you know, don’t say a word. She’s starting to panic.
You can’t tell me anything. Just because your wife died...
Silvia.
Don’t! You protect me! You protect me! That’s your fucking job! Do it. Do your job. Do it. Do it. He starts to touch her. She won’t let him.
Leave. I don’t want you here. Leave. Now! (a beat) Leave. Please. Leave. Tobin goes to the door and exits.
INT. TOBIN’S CAR - NIGHT Tobin looks the picture of Kuman-Kuman’s body by the dome light. He’s still parked in front of Silvia’s building. His cell rings.
Hello? (no response) Hello? He lowers his window, looks up at Silvia’s dark apartment
Hello? Finally, a voice reaches him, raw, weak, flat...

If he’s dead, turn out the light. Silvia disconnects. Tobin looks up at her windows. He can see nothing. He rea up and turns out the dome light. Unsure what to do next, he sits in the cold dark. He wait He can hear occasional sounds of the City. A train. A car horn on the FDR. A distant garage truck’s reverse warning And then - low and barely audible - he hears the wails of woman in deep and horrible grief.
Fog. The Protest has grown to over a hundred. A respectab detachment of NYPD officers have been assigned to them. The Protestors chant...
Zauwanie kills! Zuwanie kiils!
Silvia wears sunglasses as she walks to platform’s edge. Commuters around her read tabloids, sip coffee, work PDA’ A train can be heard rumbling loudly down the tracks.  64.

Express train. Please step back. Express train. Please step back. As the train approaches, Silvia doesn’t move. She looks d Her toes extend just over the platform’s edge. A deafening ROAR of an emergency horn as the train enters station. The train BARRELS past her, inches from her face Silvia doesn’t move.

A world map on the wall. A globe. A window onto the USSS field office. A very long table. Like Tobin’s office, it faces East and the Secretariat is visible in the morning Lud has Chief Wu and Rory laughing Tobin leads Lemann, Do and Mohammad into the room. Mohammad hands out reports as Lemann and Dot take their seats. Tobin holds up a file with a photocopied passport photo o the Skinny African clipped to the outside. TOBIN (cont‘d) Kenneth Tebiki. He arrived on a tourist visa eighteen days ago carrying a Zambian passport. We think he’s our suicide bomber. He tosses the file on the table and holds up another with photocopied drivers license photo of the Janitor. TOBIN (cont’d) Your janitor’s real name is Adimba Nujoma. South African. A cell phone registered to him got a call froma Cape Town pay phone Thursday night. The print pattern suggests he’s the bomb-maker. The name and social he used to gain employment belonged to a deceased Gap employee in Oakland. Neither man is a known terrorist operative. Tobin sits. Everyone speaks quickly...
What makes you think Tebiki was the bomber?  65.
He needed a return ticket to get a visa. He cashed it in and used the credit to book Nujoma on a Saturday flight to Paris.
Business or coach? Tobin gives her a look, asks Rory...
Did you check Nujoma’s UN locker?
We found a battery and wire. But he had two more shifts before tomorrow - one to walk the bomb through, one to. bring in the shrapnel.
Your men wouldn’t stop a guy toting big bags of screws?
No, the janitor’s ID badges are the same as general maintenance.
They were prepared.
And frugal.
So who are they? The first pause. Nils Lud looks a Polaroid of the pipe bo
The bomb is simple, crude. It looks like AFP.
The AFP doesn’t have a presence in Zambia. According to his passport, Tebiki made one trip in his entire life. He came to New York City.
The passport is certainly a fake.  66.
Or he could be a viatical.
What’s a viatical?
Someone with a terminal illness who does a suicide attack in exchange fora large payment to his.» family.
In advance. (to Mohammad) Have the corner check Mr. Tebiki’s T-cell count. (to Lemann) Was video equipment found on scene?
No. Why? Shari opens the door.
Problem.
Tobin runs. We realize he’s inside the...

Tobin is hurrying toward the open door of the English boo INT. ENGLISH TRANSLATORS’ BOOTH {SECURITY COUNCIL) Silvia waits as Tobin enters. She looks like she hasn’t slept. She closes the door behind him.
I keep getting calls. No matter where I am. This booth. The GA. It rings until someone picks up. She points to the phone. Like all phones in the building, has a clunky retro quality.
What do they say?  67.
Nothing. They hang up, wait five minutes and call again. But they never say anything. Its happened thirty-five, forty times.
What if your mic’s on.
The light flashes. The door suddenly opens. It’s Audrey.
Sorry. {to Silvia) “Monday Morning Quarterback”?
Deciduer café du Commerce.
Merci. Audrey senses something is wrong; she looks Tobin over.
Bye. Audrey exits. An awkward pause.
I’m sorry. I wasn’t sure who...
It’s okay. Tobin looks down onto the Council below. TOBIN’S POV: the British Ambassador has the floor.
Mr. Zuwanie must lay out a clear program of democratization if this Council is to... Back on Tobin and Siivia.
Are you sure this where you need to be today?  68.
No. I didn’t want to be alone. He watches her a moment. The phone rings. Silvia jumps. T answers as the second ring starts.
Hello? A distant click. Tobin puts.his fingers.on.the cradle.
Is this an outside line? She nods. He hits *-6-9. And waits.
It’s ringing. Ring two. He gestures for her come closer. They share the piece. Their cheeks almost touch. A distant ring. Tobin and Silvia listen to ring four. A machine answers..
Sorry. I can’t come to the phone right now, but here’s the beep. Silvia gasps.
What?! Who is it?!
Me.
From your machine at home?! She can only nod.

INT. HALLWAY TO SILVIA’S APARTMENT ~ DAY Dot clicks off her gun’s safety. Silvia is behind her. To gingerly turns the key in the lock and pushes the door op INT. SILVIA’S LIVING ROOM Dot and Tobin enter: the place has been completely RANSAC  69. The take a moment to register the chaos. Silvia stands in doorway.
I think it’s safe to say whoever’s behind our threat isn’t back home watching “Lifestyles of the Rich and Dictatorial”. Silvia views the room without emotion.
Tobin and Dot join an Advance Team meeting. Twenty-three enforcement types stand in a circle. All holsters are emp Lemann indicates himself.
A group of a Six NYPD Uniforms.
NYPD. I’m Intel. (indicating) And that’s Traffic. Terrorist Task Force. Sniper Team. And Bomb Squad.
Homeland. Tobin points to a Man in White Uniform, a Suit, and Dot.
Coast Guard. NSA. Secret Service. Agent Woods is our detail leader. Dot stands in front of Four Men. Chief Wu stands flanked Rory and Six UN Investigators.

Alright, let’s get started. At ten- thirty tomorrow the UN goes on security alert, that means all transit areas will be clear and secure. Service will bring Zuwanie through here at ten-fifty-eight.  70.
We’1ll have five agents working the man. We take him up those stairs to the Greenroom.
The Green Room is our safe room. (pointing) The Public Lobby will be closed all morning for-law-enforcement..use....No one gets in without a badge.
Personnel lists are due today.
How are you restricting access?
Accredited press and employees have already been issued special tags.
And Zuwanie’s entourage?
They go through the scanner like everybody else. Protocol allows each visiting dignitary one guard with one handgun. Zuwanie’s not even getting that.
Delegates?
Delegates are a problem, we have to rely on the member states to inform us if somebody doesn’t belong. Moans. Chief Wu waves them down.
We have one chance to keep Zuwanie alive: make it impossible to get a weapon inside the building.
Dot stands at the famous podium and addresses the Assembl  71.
...And another thing, pay your damn parking tickets.

Gun! Dot is grabbed by Four Secret Service Agents and whisked the podium. They drag her to the Green Room using their h as guns. UN Cops provide cover. The Hall is empty. The Assembly is at lunch. Chief Wu tim the exercise from the floor with a stopwatch. Tobin and R stand beside him CHIEF WU (cont’d) Eighteen seconds! Mohammad enters from the Foyer and gestures for Tobin.

Just off the hallway between the GA and Conference Buildi A quiet area used by UN tour guides, so there’s a small m of the UN near the door. On one wall is an aerial photo o with the words “International Territory” written above. Diplomats move up and down the Hallway on the other side the glass. Mohammad leads Tobin down it. They enter, look for a quiet place to talk.
Tebiki had AIDS. Full blown. And Nujoma had two prior bullet wounds, one within the last year. Coroner found grenade shrapnel in his leg. These facts spin through Tobin’s head.
He was a mercenary.
A merc and a viatical, that makes this a money job.
Why make it look like a terrorist attack? Why do it in the UN?  72. Tobin looks to the UN model, then the aerial photo across room. He registers the words INTERNATIONAL TERRITORY. cuoT To:
Jon (the CIA guy) sits across from his Boyfriend, who’s n happy that Jon’s taken a cell call...
Nils Lud?
Tobin talks on his cell while pacing up and down in front the frozen pool.
Would he sell Zuwanie out?!
Jon stands from the table.
He’d sell his children for parts. (to his Boyfriend) I know, I promised. Jon moves to a window, out of earshot of other patrons.

Okay, let’s say Nils Lud is being paid to arrange a hit on Zuwanie, by the Ku, by the AFP, by a very forward-thinking philanthropist, whoever. Doesn’t matter. (the old questicn) Why do it in the United Nations?
Tobin as before.

It’s international territory. (he stops pacing) Anywhere else, Lud’s responsible. States let a visiting dignitary’s security force control their man. But the UN doesn’t. Wu’s not even allowing him the usual armed guard.  73. Tobin looks up at the towering Secretariat.
This is the only place on the planet where a security consultant can’t be held responsible for his client’s safety.
Jon considers the possibilities.
And if he’s not responsible, no one can say he was involved. There’s no fall-out. Professional or criminal.
Yeah. Jon smiles.
Clean. It’s out there. But it’s clean.

EXT. SILVIA’S BUILDING - DAY Two NYPD Officers stand in the doorway. INT. SILVIA’S LIVING ROOM Still. Ransacked chaos. She hasn’t bothered to clean up. INT. SILVIA’S BEDROOM It, too, has been ransacked. We hear the shower. INT. SILVIA’S BATHROOM Silvia lies in fetal position on the tub floor. The showe rains down on her, creating a small pool around her body. She stares at drops hitting in the water.
INT. DOT’S CAR - DAY Dot drives. She uses her sleeve to clear the windshield. Tobin adjusts her defroster. They’re stuck in traffic.
I know what he’ll say. He’1ll say, “Why the hell would Lud shoot his own men?” That’s what he’1ll say. Tobin reaches over and honks her horn.
They were worthless the second they made our suspect list. -And Tebiki was probably too sick to run. Tobin honks her horn. She gives him an exasperated look, which he’s too pre-occupied to notice.
It explains why there was no video. Terrorists always make a video, the handler needs it to make sure the bomber doesn’t back out. When Tobin reaches for the horn, she hits his hand
If Lud organized the attack, why ransack Silvia’s place? He’s only telling us it’s not over.
No idea. Something Nujoma said that night must scare him. Unless... CUT To:

A very small strip of grass behind Beekman Place. The sor hidden park used by drug dealers and leash-law violators. FDR is on the other side of a cyclone fence. Tobin, Dot and Silvia hug themselves in the cold. Over th roar of surging traffic, Tobin completes the sentence fro the previous scene...
Could Lud be the man you heard?
If he picked up French from his soldiers, he might mimic their pronunciation. It’s possible. But even if I heard him say the exact same phrase, I couldn’t be sure.
He doesn’t know that. 75. A man with a dog appears at the park entrance. He sees it occupied and moves on.

Lud is travelling on a dipiomatic passport. The evidentiary standard to-get-him-in. protective. custody is high. But if we make him think you can identify his voice, he may try to contact you. He may offer you money. He may threaten you again, directly. He may threaten people you know. Here. Or in Matobo. He may come after you. If we can catch him doing any of those things, we'd have evidence. Only the three of us would be involved. It would mean heightening your exposure. Silvia looks from Tobin to Dot. They don’t have to tell h the proposal is a flagrant violation of procedure.
You can say yes or no. A beat. The traffic roars.
Can I ask you something?
Of course.
If I were standing beside Zuwanie and you saw a man with a gun. If you could only grab one of us. If you had one second to decide. Who would you save?
Zauwanie. And I wouldn’t need the second. Silvia stares at Tobin. Neither one looks away. Finally, smiles a slows smile.
I'll help.
Thank you.
With one proviso. I want a handgun. To keep at home Just for a few days. Until all this blows over. Tobin and Dot exchange a look. DOT. We can’t just give you a gun.
You’ re asking me to risk my life.
We can protect you, Ms. Broome. That’s sorta our job.
Your job is to protect Zuwanie.
We can protect you, too.
Can you? She looks at him for a hard moment.
Yes. A beat. She nods a reluctant concession.

EXT. HOWARD JOHNSON’S RESTAURANT (TIMES SQUARE) - DAY A steady stream of bulky tourists passes. A lost balloon floats above them, up among winter steam and neon. Through a window, we see Tobin sits alone in a booth whil speaking into a voice recorder. Edgar’s book is on the ta in front of him. Nils Lud passes by outside. INT. HOWARD-JOHNSON’S RESTAURANT It’s moderately quiet given the crowds and chaos outside. enters and comes to Tobin, who’s saying into the recorder  77.
Rave the linguistic tech check it. (he gestures Lud to sit) And tell Ms. Broome she can review the last of the tapes when she’s in the office during Zuwanie’s speech. Tobin lowers the voice recorder.
You speak French don’t you?
Yes.
How would you say, “Edmond Zuwanie will die in this room?”
Edmond Zuwanie va mourir dans cette Chambre meme. Tobin moves his hand so Lud can see the voice recorder’s light is illuminated.
Say it again. He holds the Dictaphone to Lud’s mouth. Lud stares at it a moment. He’s stuck. Then with false confidence...
Edmond Zuwanie va mourir dans cette Chambre meme. Tobin hits stop.
Chambre. Beautiful word.
Your investigation continues?
Somebody broke into Ms. Broome’s apartment this morning. Nils Lud looks like he’s getting information he can’t qui comprehend. Tobin sets the voice recorder on the table.  78.

These interpreters are amazing. I had her reviewing tapes of various diplomats speaking French this morning. She’d hear three words and say, “Rotsi. He’s a Caprivian.” I’ve never even heard of Caprivia.
Caprivi. It.is.in.Western. Namibia.
That’s helpful. Lud puts on his best false smile.
Why did you wish to see me, Agent Keller?

I just needed your French on tape. We’re checking everyone security cameras picked up leaving the UN Thursday after ten p.m. You left... (checking a document) ...at eleven-twenty-two. Pro forma. Tobin mimics the mercenaries smile. Lud looks at the voic recorder in the middle of the table, as if taunting him. The Waitress approaches. Tobin gestures for the check.
You’re not worried, are you? Lud laughs. He stands.
Right, then.
See you, tomorrow. Oh, one more thing. About the other night... (a beat) Thank you. The South African nods and limps for the door.

The Lobby is closed, dark and locked. Silvia stand with a knapsack at her feet. She’s locking u the sculpture of Africa below, lost in painful thought. The UN COP guarding her enters the frame behind her...
(concerned) Ms. Broome?
Can you do a favor? Can you give a few minutes? If you’d wait out in the Hall, make sure no one comes?
Of course. And he leaves her at her make shift memorial.

text: A sea of umbrellas. Neon lights obscured by rain. Tourist huddle in the rain and sleet beneath a lingerie poster. Lud moves comes out of the Marriott wearing a plastic rai coat. Dot, obscured by a cap and poncho, follows.
INT. SILVIA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Silvia turns on her bedside lamp and sits up in bed. Afte moment, her phone rings. It startles her.
Tobin stands at a window. A hooded camping lantern is on near-by chair, as is Edgar’s book. Tobin speaks on his cell while looking into Silvia’s bedr
You okay?  80. INTERCUT between the BEDROOM and SURVEILLANCE APARTMENT:
No. A beat. She lays on her side and looks up at his darkened window. can’t see him, but she knows which window he’s in.
I can’t see you. He turns up a camping lantern on a chair until he can see own reflection.
Talk to me.
(re: Edgar) You haven’t told anyone, have you? She doesn’t respond. He can hear her breathing. When they speak, it’s in quiet tones and long pauses...
Just my guard at the UN.
Why not?
I hate condolences. That extra sincere tone. The forced eye- contact. The two-handed handshake.
I hated the advice. “You have to get out of bed every morning.”
“This will make you stronger.”
“Be thankful for the memories.”
“Remind yourself he’s better off.” She gets out of bed and paces in front of the window.  A beat. 81.
Tell me about your wife.
What do you want to know?
What do you miss about her?

Simple things. Sound of her key in the door. The weight of her leg on mine. The smell of her pillow. Jenn used to have this saying, usually for when I forgot to do something. She’d say, “Honey, love is a slow river of small details.”
That’s beautiful. And cruel.
Cruel?
The sexiest thing a man can do is express love for another woman - it’s the one time you can really trust him,
What do you miss about Edgar?
I miss who I was around him. I miss being naive. She wanders back to her bed and lies down.

We were walking one night through Toronto. It was our second date. A homeless woman came up. She kept saying, swear to God. “I’m gonna buy food. Swear to God. Just food. Swear to God.” Edgar gave her twenty dollars. She left. Happy. I said, “You realize she’s not going to buy food.” He said, “I wasn’t giving her money, I was giving her trust.” (MORE)
SILVIA (cont'd) (a beat) I took him home and fucked him, But these days... A long pause.
You okay? Click. She’s gone. He watches her. She’s lost in thought, as if she’s forgot him. She reaches up turns out the light. He does the same Tobin stands in the dark.

Twenty passengers wait, wet, cold. Lud comes down stairs onto the platform. Dot follows a fe seconds later, pretending to check her cell’s display. Bu Lud does not look back. In fact, he doesn’t even stop. He moves with steady purpose up another flight of stairs.

Narrow. Twisting. It’s one of those long passages that le to another station. A violin plays somewhere in the maze. Dot hurries along. Though she only gets fleeting glimpses Lud’s plastic coat, she keeps his footsteps in front of h As she turns a corner, he’s gone. She jumps back. Listens She hears his footsteps receding. She peeks around the co to see there is an adjoining passage just ahead. Dot peeks around the corner. DOT’S POV: The adjoining passage quickly dead ends at an accordion gate. The gate open. She pulls her head back and waits. After a few seconds... DOT’S POV: The adjoining passage is now empty.
Dot makes her way to the gate, unsnapping her holster. Th gate’s chain looks like it’s been cut. Stairs on the othe lead down to a brightly lit subway platform.  83.
Shit. Dot hurriedly squeezes through the gate.

Tobin reads “The» Casual. Dead”...Something..makes. him s he closes the book for a moment and takes up the binocula BINOCULAR POV: Silvia is in bed asleep. He scopes her Liv Room. The apartment door is closed. The window onto the f escape is closed.

Filthy. Graffiti. Homeless detritus. Visible on the tile is a partial station plate for “Lexington Ave.” Dot comes down the stairs, surprised to find the platform abandoned yet brightly lit. She takes out her weapon. Behind her, the last thirty feet of platform is stacked w old school desks the City stored and forgot. In front of the north end is sixty yards away. A row of thin iron pil runs along the tracks. Dot advances north, using the pillars for cover. Thirty yards ahead is a SECOND STAIRWELL leading up into darkness. Dot listens at the tracks. She comes back through the row of pillars and walks to th center of the platform. Then - with an eerie metallic clang - the LIGHTS GO OUT. Black. Pure Black.
Shit. We hear her breathing. Then after a few seconds... A footstep. Dot stops breathing. Was it a footstep? There’s a rustling sound. Again.
Hello? Silence. A crunch.

Hello? Nothing. FLASH. Dot fires toward the tracks. She’s using the powde flash to see the platform to the north. It’s empty. FLASH. Tobin watches Silvia. FLASH. Dot. fires to check the platform to the south. Emp FLASH. Silvia suddenly opens her eyes. FLASH. Dot fires to look behind her. Nothing. Black.  85. Silence. Dot’s poncho rustles with the sound of aiming in the dark DoT (sotto) Shit. Silence. Dot’s face appears in the light of cell phone display.
INT. SURVEILLANCE APARTMENT -— NIGHT Tobin on his cell phone, irritated.
Alright, I’m on my way. Tobin disconnects and raises his binoculars. BINOCULAR POV: Silvia lies in bed. He picks up his cell phone and hits re-dial.
Sorry to wake. you. BINOCULAR POV: Silvia holds the phone.
I wasn’t asleep. Tobin lowers the binoculars.
I have to leave you alone for a few minutes. Fifteen at the most. (he checks the street) He may be up to something. INT. SILVIA’S BEDROOM Silvia sits up.
I’1l be okay. Go ahead. She hangs up. She considers her empty apartment.

EXT. SILVIA’S STREET - NIGHT Rain. Tobin exits the building that houses his surveillan apartment. He looks up and down the street. Quiet. The NY patrol car is still parked at the end. He runs to his car in the rain and retrieves a flashlight

The light could’ve been on a timer. His cell phone rings. Once. By the time he gets it out of pocket it’s stopped. Instinctively, they both look at the CLOSE on the phone display: “Silvia Broome”. SILVIA’S BATHROOM Silvia winces as she hears the bedroom door open. INT. SILVIA’S BEDROOM Lud looks around. He moves toward the closed bathroom doo the intercom buzzes out in the living room.
